TypeSignature.Value: public class UITableViewCell : UIKit.UIView, IDisposable, UIKit.IUIGestureRecognizerDelegate

.class public auto ansi beforefieldinit UITableViewCell extends UIKit.UIView implements class Foundation.INSCoding, class ObjCRuntime.INativeObject, class UIKit.IUIGestureRecognizerDelegate, class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: A that displays an element displayed by the . Cells can be reused.

remarks.para: A represents a single cell (row) in a . s are typically allocated in the method of if returns . (See discussion at or ).
There are four predefined styles, which can be created by using the constructor. These predefined styles appear as follows:

All of the predefined styles have and properties of type and all but have a of type . Assignment to the
property of a cell initialized with the style will result in a runtime exception.

A may combine its with a assigned to its property. Accessory views are often used with standard s, such as a checkmark or disclosure indicator. When being edited, a will combine its
with an editing control on the left and, optionally, a reordering control on the right.
In a non-selected cell, the is displayed, while a selected cell will show its view.
To customize s, application developers can either customize the views used by one of the predefined styles or can subclass . (In addition, application developers will often override .)
Starting with iOS 8, table view cells can be auto-sized, and no longer require the to be implemented to size cells. To do this, the cell constructor should set the constraints.

block.para: Application developers should prefer subclassing over extensive customization of predefined styles. Xamarin's experience is that subclassing is less error-prone. Although subclassing introduces the normal overhead of a new class, this is generally a minor trade-off in comparison to the importance and complexity of the customized cell.
Because s appear rapidly during scrolling, application developers should avoid layout recalculations and higher-cost rendering techniques such as the use of transparent views.
Application developers should make a strong effort to reuse cells with the method of .

Docs.summary: Default constructor that initializes a new instance of this class with no parameters.

MemberSignature.Value: public UITableViewCell (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSCoder coder);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSCoder coder) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor that initializes the object from the data stored in the unarchiver object.

remarks.para: This constructor is provided to allow the class to be initialized from an unarchiver (for example, during NIB deserialization). This is part of the protocol.

If developers want to create a subclass of this object and continue to support deserialization from an archive, they should implement a constructor with an identical signature: taking a single parameter of type and decorate it with the [Export("initWithCoder:"] attribute declaration.
The state of this object can also be serialized by using the companion method, EncodeTo.

MemberSignature.Value: protected UITableViewCell (MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t);
.method familyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSObjectFlag t) cil managed

Docs.summary: Constructor to call on derived classes to skip initialization and merely allocate the object.

remarks.para: This constructor should be called by derived classes when they completely construct the object in managed code and merely want the runtime to allocate and initialize the NSObject. This is required to implement the two-step initialization process that Objective-C uses, the first step is to perform the object allocation, the second step is to initialize the object. When developers invoke the constructor that takes the NSObjectFlag.Empty they take advantage of a direct path that goes all the way up to NSObject to merely allocate the object's memory and bind the Objective-C and C# objects together. The actual initialization of the object is up to the developer.

This constructor is typically used by the binding generator to allocate the object, but prevent the actual initialization to take place. Once the allocation has taken place, the constructor has to initialize the object. With constructors generated by the binding generator this means that it manually invokes one of the "init" methods to initialize the object.
It is the developer's responsibility to completely initialize the object if they chain up using the NSObjectFlag.Empty path.

In general, if the developer's constructor invokes the NSObjectFlag.Empty base implementation, then it should be calling an Objective-C init method. If this is not the case, developers should instead chain to the proper constructor in their class.

The argument value is ignored and merely ensures that the only code that is executed is the construction phase is the basic NSObject allocation and runtime type registration. Typically the chaining would look like this:

MemberSignature.Value: protected UITableViewCell (IntPtr handle);
.method familyorassemblyhidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(native int handle) cil managed

Docs.summary: A constructor used when creating managed representations of unmanaged objects; Called by the runtime.

remarks.para: This constructor is invoked by the runtime infrastructure () to create a new managed representation for a pointer to an unmanaged Objective-C object. Developers should not invoke this method directly, instead they should call the GetNSObject method as it will prevent two instances of a managed object to point to the same native object.

MemberSignature.Value: public UITableViewCell (MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellStyle style, MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString reuseIdentifier);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellStyle style, class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString reuseIdentifier) cil managed

Docs.param: The style to use for this cell.

param.name: reuseIdentifier
param.para: A string used to identify the cell object if it should be reused for mutiple rows in a table view. Pass if the object should not be reused. The same reuse identifier string should be used for all cells that use the same class and layout.

Docs.summary: Create a table cell with the given style and reuse identifier.

remarks.para: The reuse identifier is associated with all cells (rows) in a table view that have the same layout (irrespective of their content) and can therefore be used interchangeably. The implementation calls with a specific reuse identifier string to obtain a cached cell object with a particular layout to use as the basis for the row being constructed for viewing.
To produce a layout different to those built-in to , create a custom cell. To set the row height of each cell differently, implement .

The implementation calls with a specific reuse identifier string to obtain a cached cell object with a particular layout to use as the basis for the row being constructed for viewing.

MemberSignature.Value: public UITableViewCell (MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGRect frame);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype MonoTouch.CoreGraphics.CGRect frame) cil managed

Docs.param: Frame used by the view, expressed in iOS points.
Docs.summary: Initializes the UITableViewCell with the specified frame.

remarks.para: This constructor is used to programmatically create a new instance of UITableViewCell with the specified dimension in the frame. The object will only be displayed once it has been added to a view hierarchy by calling AddSubview in a containing view.
This constructor is not invoked when deserializing objects from storyboards or XIB filesinstead the constructor that takes an NSCoder parameter is invoked.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellAccessory Accessory { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellAccessory Accessory

Docs.summary: The type of standard accessory the cell should use (in its normal state).

remarks.para: If specified, the accessory view appears on the right side of a cell. Standard accessory view types include the 'disclosure indicator' right-chevron.
If the accessory type is (and the cell is enabled) then when tapped it will call the method. This method is seperate to the method that is called if the rest of the cell is tapped.
If a custom accessory view is set via then this Accessory property is ignored.

The accessory image cross-fades between normal and editing states if it is set for both states; use the property to set the accessory type to be displayed in editing mode. If an accessory is not defined for both states (normal and editing) the the accessory is animated to slide in or out, as required.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView AccessoryView { get; set; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView AccessoryView

Docs.summary: A view on the right side of a UITableViewCell (normal state).

remarks.para: If this property is not then the cell uses the given view as the accessory (for the normal state). The value of the is ignored when AccessoryView is set. The custom accessory view can be a control, a label or a custom view.

The accessory view cross-fades between normal and editing states if it is set for both states; use the property to set a custom accessory view to be displayed in editing mode. If an accessory is not defined for both states (normal and editing) the the accessory view is animated to slide in or out, as required.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCell.UITableViewCellAppearance Appearance { get; }
.property class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCell/UITableViewCellAppearance Appearance

Docs.summary: Strongly-typed property that returns the UIAppearance class for this class.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on this instance will affect the appearance of all instances of UITableViewCell.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UITableViewCell, they should use the method.

MemberSignature.Value: public static MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCell.UITableViewCellAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn (Type[] containers);
.method public static hidebysig class MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCell/UITableViewCellAppearance AppearanceWhenContainedIn(class System.Type[] containers) cil managed

Docs.param: List of types that developers want to have as the containers to apply this particular appearance
Docs.summary: Returns a strongly typed UIAppearance for instances of this class when the view is hosted in the specified hierarchy.
Docs.returns: The appearance proxy object that developers can use to set properties when the given container hierarchy is active

remarks.para: The returned object represents the UIAppearance proxy where developers can set appearance properties for instances of UITableViewCell when those instances are contained in the hierarchy specified by the parameter.
If developers want to control the appearance of subclasses of UITableViewCell, they should use the method.
The following example shows how the AppearanceWhenContainedIn method works

example.code: var mySliders = UISlider.AppearanceWhenContainedIn (typeof (UINavigationBar), typeof (UIPopoverController)); mySliders.TintColor = UIColor.Red;

remarks.para: For more information, see the documentation for the class.

value.para: (More documentation for this node is coming)

MemberSignature.Value: public override IntPtr ClassHandle { get; }
.property instance native int ClassHandle

Docs.summary: The handle for this class.
Docs.value: The pointer to the Objective-C class.
Docs.remarks: Each MonoTouch class mirrors an unmanaged Objective-C class. This value contains the pointer to the Objective-C class, it is similar to calling objc_getClass with the object name.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView ContentView { get; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView ContentView

Docs.summary: Returns the content view of the cell object (read-only).
Docs.remarks: This property returns the default superview for content displayed in the cell. To customize cells with additional views, add them to the content view so they will be positioned correctly as the cell transitions in and out of editing mode.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UILabel DetailTextLabel { get; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UILabel DetailTextLabel

Docs.summary: Returns the secondary label of the table cell (read-only).

remarks.para: UITableViewCell automatically creates the secondary (detail) label if the cell is created with a that supports a detail label.
If the cell's style doesn't support a detail label, this property returns .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void DidTransitionToState (MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellState mask);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void DidTransitionToState(valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellState mask) cil managed

Docs.param: A bit mask indicating the state (or combination of states) the cell is transitioning to.
Docs.summary: Called on the cell just after it transitions between cell states.

remarks.para: UITableViewCell subclasses can implement this method to perform additional animations when it is changing state (such as from a normal state to editing move). This method is called at the end of the animation block to clean up after the state change (such as removing the editing and reordering controls when transitioning from editing to normal mode).
Subclasses must always call when overriding this method.
Note that when the user swipes to delete, the cell transitions to the - but is not set. Remember to test for the correct value when handling this case.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void DragStateDidChange (MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellDragState dragState);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void DragStateDidChange(valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellDragState dragState) cil managed

Docs.summary: Method that is called when the cell's drag state changes.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool Editing { get; set; }
.property instance bool Editing

Docs.summary: Whether the cell is in an editable state.
Docs.value: if the cell is in the editing state, if the cell is in the normal state.
Docs.remarks: In the editing state, a cell displays the editing controls specified for it: the green insertion control or the red deletion control on the left, and/or the reordering control on the right. Use and to specify which controls appear in the cell.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellAccessory EditingAccessory { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellAccessory EditingAccessory

Docs.summary: The type of standard accessory the cell should use (in its editing state).

remarks.para: If specified, the accessory view appears on the right side of a cell. Standard accessory types include the 'disclosure indicator' right-chevron.
If the accessory type is (and the cell is enabled) then when tapped it will call the method. This method is seperate to the method that is called if the rest of the cell is tapped.
If a custom accessory view is set for the editing state via then this EditingAccessory property is ignored.

The accessory image cross-fades between normal and editing states if it is set for both states; use the property to set the accessory type to be displayed in the normal state. If an accessory is not defined for both states (normal and editing) the the accessory is animated to slide in or out, as required.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView EditingAccessoryView { get; set; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView EditingAccessoryView

Docs.summary: A view on the right side of a UITableViewCell (editing state).

remarks.para: If this property is not then the cell uses the given view as the accessory (for the editing state). The value of the is ignored when EditingAccessoryView is set. The custom accessory view can be a control, a label or a custom view.

The accessory view cross-fades between normal and editing states if it is set for both states; use the property to set a custom accessory view to be displayed in the normal state. If an accessory is not defined for both states (normal and editing) the the accessory view is animated to slide in or out, as required.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellEditingStyle EditingStyle { get; }
.property instance valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellEditingStyle EditingStyle

Docs.summary: The editing style of the cell (read-only). Returns whether the cell is in an editable state, and if so whether it is showing an insertion or deletion control.
Docs.value: The default value is (the cell is not currently editable).

remarks.para: The method returns the value for each cell.

remarks.para: This method is part of the protocol and is used by applications to preserve the state of the object into an archive.
Users will typically create a and then invoke the which will call into this method

If developers want to allow their object to be archived, they should override this method and store their state in using the provided parameter. In addition, developers should also implement a constructor that takes an NSCoder argument and is exported with [Export ("initWithCoder:")]

Docs.typeparam: The type for which the UIAppearance proxy must be returned. This is a subclass of UITableViewCell.

summary.para: Obtains the appearance proxy for the subclass of UITableViewCell.

returns.para: appearance proxy object for the specified type.

remarks.para: Setting any appearance properties on the returned object will affect the appearance of all classes and subclasses of the type parameter.
Unlike the property, or the method which only work on instances of this particular class, the proxies returned by GetAppearance can be used to change the style of subclasses.
The following example shows how the GetAppearance method works
For more information, see the documentation for the class.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool Highlighted { get; set; }
.property instance bool Highlighted

Docs.summary: Whether the cell is highlighted.

remarks.para: Highlighting affects the appearance of labels, the image and background. When Highlighted is , the labels in the cell are drawn in their highlighted text color (which is white by default).
When this property is set to , the transition to the new appearance is not animated. Use the method for animated highlight-state transitions.
For highlighting to work properly, set the for the two labels ( and ), and set the property on the cell's .

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIImageView ImageView { get; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIImageView ImageView

Docs.summary: Returns the image view of the table cell (read-only).
Docs.remarks: The image appears on the left hand side of the cell, forcing the labels to move to the right. The image view object is created when the cell is created but initially there is no image set.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual nint IndentationLevel { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype System.nint IndentationLevel

Docs.summary: Sets the indentation level of a cell, shifting the position of the cell's content.
Docs.remarks: The width of each level of indentation is determined by property.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual nfloat IndentationWidth { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype System.nfloat IndentationWidth

Docs.summary: The width of each the indentation level.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView MultipleSelectionBackgroundView { get; set; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView MultipleSelectionBackgroundView

Docs.summary: The background view used when a cell is selected inside a table view that allows multiple selection.
Docs.remarks: If this property is not , it is used as the background view for any selected cells (when the containing table view allows mutiple selection). Mulitple selection is set on a using the and properties.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void PrepareForReuse ();
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void PrepareForReuse() cil managed

Docs.summary: Prepares a cell for reuse by the table view's .

remarks.para: If a is reusable - it has a ReuseIdentifier - this method is called just before the object is returned by . This method implementation should reset cell attributes that are not content-related, such as alpha, editing, and selection state. The should always reset the content when reusing a cell.
Subclasses must always call when overriding this method.
If the cell object does not have a , this method is not called.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString ReuseIdentifier { get; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.Foundation.NSString ReuseIdentifier

Docs.summary: A string that identifies a cell object so that it can be reused.

remarks.para: The ReuseIdentifier is set in the cell's constructor and cannot be changed. When cells disappear from view, the object maintains a queue of those cell objects so they can be reused. The implementation then uses with a given ReuseIdentifier to retrieve an existing cell of the correct type for reuse.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool Selected { get; set; }
.property instance bool Selected

Docs.summary: Whether the cell is selected.

remarks.para: Selection affects the appearance of labels, image and background. When the Selected property is set to , the labels are drawn in white and the background is set to the (if set).
When this property is set to , the transition to the new appearance is not animated. Use the method for animated selection-state transitions.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView SelectedBackgroundView { get; set; }
.property instance class MonoTouch.UIKit.UIView SelectedBackgroundView

Docs.summary: The view that is used as the cell's background when it is selected.

value.para: Default is for Plain tables and non- for Grouped style tables.

remarks.para: adds the value of this proerty as a subview only when the cell is selected. It is added as a subview directly above the if that is not , otherwise behind all other views.
If is called, this view is animated in and out with an alpha fade.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellSelectionStyle SelectionStyle { get; set; }
.property instance valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellSelectionStyle SelectionStyle

Docs.summary: The selection style for a cell.
Docs.remarks: The selection style determines the color of a cell when it is selected.

to animate the appearance/disappearance of the editing controls, to immediately show/hide the controls.

to animate the highlight transition, to make the transition immediate.
Docs.summary: Sets the highlighted state of the cell, optionally animating the transition between states.

remarks.para: Highlights or unhighlights the cell, animating the transition if is . Highlighting changes the appearance of the cell's labels, image, and background.
For highlighting to work properly, set the for the two labels ( and ), and set the property on the cell's .
Custom cells can override this method to make additional changes when transitioning between states.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool ShowingDeleteConfirmation { get; set; }

Docs.summary: Whether the delete confirmation button is currently showing in the cell (read-only).

remarks.para: When the deletion control (red cirle to the left of the cell) is showing and is tapped, the cell displays a Delete button on the right side of the cell (which is when this method returns ).
The text displayed in the Delete button is localized.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool ShowsReorderControl { get; set; }
.property instance bool ShowsReorderControl

Docs.summary: Whether the reordering control is currently showing in the cell (read-only).

remarks.para: The reordering control consists of three grey, horizontal lines on the right side of the cell. Dragging this control causes the entire cell to be moved to another position in the table.
The reordering control only appears if this property is set and the method has been implemented on the . The reordering control can be selectively hidden on specific rows by returning from

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual void WillTransitionToState (MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellState mask);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance void WillTransitionToState(valuetype MonoTouch.UIKit.UITableViewCellState mask) cil managed

Docs.param: A bit mask indicating the state/s the cell is transitioning to.
Docs.summary: Called on the cell just before it transitions between states.

remarks.para: UITableViewCell subclasses can implement this method to perform additional animations when it is changing state (such as from a normal state to editing move). A custom cell may create any new views that are required in the new state. is then called which allows the code to position these new elements in their correct locations for the new state.
Subclasses must always call when overriding this method.
Note that when the user swipes to delete, the cell transitions to the - but is not set. Remember to test for the correct value when handling this case.
